body:
Received an email with just single link in the body.

http://derbor.com/fvwd/fox_newsx.php

On desktop, it forwards to http://com-zg88.net/indexer.php?a=298712&c=wl_con&s=18f and then to http://womenshealth.com-zg88.net/diet/report-us/

But on mobile phone, it forwards to http://mobile.downloadmobilessoftware.ru/FLVupdate.php and starts downloading Security.Update.apk right away.

Most US Android devices however, by default disallow installation of apps from sources other than Google Play. So we're safe for now.

It is mildly interesting how web services in this scam work.

Let's play with curl

$ curl http://mobile.downloadmobilessoftware.ru/FLVupdate.php

<html><head>
<script type="text/javascript">
window.top.location=document.URL.replace("FLVupdate.php","FLVupdate2.php");
</script>
</head><body></body></html>

Looks like a simple URL rewrite. Try again.

$ curl http://mobile.downloadmobilessoftware.ru/FLVupdate2.php

Empty. Faking Nexus 5 user agent...

$ curl -A "Mozilla/5.0 (Linux; Android 4.4; Nexus 5 Build/KRT16M) \
AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Version/4.0 \
Chrome/30.0.0.0 Mobile Safari/537.36" \
http://mobile.downloadmobilessoftware.ru/FLVupdate2.php > Security.Update.apk

... and we got that file.

I haven't tried disassembling it, but based on Russian download URL it seems interesting. Here it is with extension changed to .txt

Security.Update.txt
